column2: THE WHITE SNAKE
column3: THE WHITE SNAKE

column2: A long time ago there lived a king who was famed for his wisdom through all the land.
column3: A long time ago there lived a king who was famed for his wisdom through all the land.

column2: Nothing was hidden from him, and it seemed as if news of the most secret things was brought to him through the air.
column3: Nothing was hidden from him, and it seemed as if news of the most secret things was brought to him through the air.

column2: But he had a strange custom; every day after dinner, when the table was cleared, and no one else was present, a trusty servant had to bring him one more dish.
column3: But he had a strange custom; every day after dinner, when the table was cleared, and no one else was present, a trusty servant had to bring him one more dish.

column2: It was covered, however, and even the servant did not know what was in it, neither did anyone know, for the king never took off the cover to eat of it until he was quite alone.
column3: It was covered, however, and even the servant did not know what was in it, neither did anyone know, for the king never took off the cover to eat of it until he was quite alone.

column2: This had gone on for a long time, when one day the servant, who took away the dish, was overcome with such curiosity that he could not help carrying the dish into his room.
column3: This had gone on for a long time, when one day the servant, who took away the dish, was overcome with such curiosity that he could not help carrying the dish into his room.

column2: When he had carefully locked the door, he lifted up the cover, and saw a white snake lying on the dish.
column3: When he had carefully locked the door, he lifted up the cover, and saw a white snake lying on the dish.

column2: Now it so happened that on this very day the queen lost her most beautiful ring, and suspicion of having stolen it fell upon this trusty servant, who was allowed to go everywhere.
column3: Now it so happened that on this very day the queen lost her most beautiful ring, and suspicion of having stolen it fell upon this trusty servant, who was allowed to go everywhere.

column2: The king ordered the man to be brought before him, and threatened with angry words that unless he could before the morrow point out the thief, he himself should be looked upon as guilty and executed.
column3: The king ordered the man to be brought before him, and threatened with angry words that unless he could before the morrow point out the thief, he himself should be looked upon as guilty and executed.

column2: In vain he declared his innocence; he was dismissed with no better answer.
column3: In vain he declared his innocence; he was dismissed with no better answer.

column2: In his trouble and fear he went down into the courtyard and took thought how to help himself out of his trouble.
column3: In his trouble and fear he went down into the courtyard and took thought how to help himself out of his trouble.

column2: The servant could now easily prove his innocence; and the king, to make amends for the wrong, allowed him to ask a favour, and promised him the best place in the court that he could wish for.
column3: The servant could now easily prove his innocence; and the king, to make amends for the wrong, allowed him to ask a favour, and promised him the best place in the court that he could wish for.

column2: When his request was granted he set out on his way, and one day came to a pond, where he saw three fishes caught in the reeds and gasping for water.
column3: When his request was granted he set out on his way, and one day came to a pond, where he saw three fishes caught in the reeds and gasping for water.

column2: Now, though it is said that fishes are dumb, he heard them lamenting that they must perish so miserably, and, as he had a kind heart, he got off his horse and put the three prisoners back into the water.
column3: Now, though it is said that fishes are dumb, he heard them lamenting that they must perish so miserably, and, as he had a kind heart, he got off his horse and put the three prisoners back into the water.

column2: He rode on, and after a while it seemed to him that he heard a voice in the sand at his feet.
column3: He rode on, and after a while it seemed to him that he heard a voice in the sand at his feet.

column2: He listened, and heard an ant-king complain: 'Why cannot folks, with their clumsy beasts, keep off our bodies?
column3: He listened, and heard an ant king complain: 'Why cannot folks, with their clumsy beasts, keep off our bodies?

column2: That stupid horse, with his heavy hoofs, has been treading down my people without mercy!' So he turned on to a side path and the ant-king cried out to him: 'We will remember you--one good turn deserves another!'
column3: That stupid horse, with his heavy hoofs, has been treading down my people without mercy!' So he turned on to a side path and the ant king cried out to him: 'We will remember you-one good turn deserves another!'

column2: 'Out with you, you idle, good-for-nothing creatures!' cried they; 'we cannot find food for you any longer; you are big enough, and can provide for yourselves.' But the poor young ravens lay upon the ground, flapping their wings, and crying: 'Oh, what helpless chicks we are!
column3: 'Out with you, you idle, good for nothing creatures!' cried they; 'we cannot find food for you any longer; you are big enough, and can provide for yourselves.' But the poor young ravens lay upon the ground, flapping their wings, and crying: 'Oh, what helpless chicks we are!

column2: We must shift for ourselves, and yet we cannot fly!
column3: We must shift for ourselves, and yet we cannot fly!

column2: What can we do, but lie here and starve?' So the good young fellow alighted and killed his horse with his sword, and gave it to them for food.
column3: What can we do, but lie here and starve?' So the good young fellow alighted and killed his horse with his sword, and gave it to them for food.

column2: Then they came hopping up to it, satisfied their hunger, and cried: 'We will remember you--one good turn deserves another!'
column3: Then they came hopping up to it, satisfied their hunger, and cried: 'We will remember you-one good turn deserves another!'

column2: And now he had to use his own legs, and when he had walked a long way, he came to a large city.
column3: And now he had to use his own legs, and when he had walked a long way, he came to a large city.

column2: But when the proud princess perceived that he was not her equal in birth, she scorned him, and required him first to perform another task.
column3: But when the proud princess perceived that he was not her equal in birth, she scorned him, and required him first to perform another task.

column2: The ant-king had come in the night with thousands and thousands of ants, and the grateful creatures had by great industry picked up all the millet-seed and gathered them into the sacks.
column3: The ant king had come in the night with thousands and thousands of ants, and the grateful creatures had by great industry picked up all the millet seed and gathered them into the sacks.

column2: But he heard a rustling in the branches, and a golden apple fell into his hand.
column3: But he heard a rustling in the branches, and a golden apple fell into his hand.
